title: Psalms Chapter 108 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 108 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 108 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 108.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:1, what is fixed that leads to singing and praise?
questions.correctAnswer: My heart
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:1 states, 'O God, my heart is fixed; I will sing and give praise.'

questions.question: In Psalms 108:2, which instruments are called to awaken?
questions.correctAnswer: Psaltery and harp
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:2 says, 'Awake, psaltery and harp: I myself will awake early.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:3, where will the psalmist praise the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Among the people and nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:3 states, 'I will praise thee, O LORD, among the people: and I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.'

questions.question: Psalms 108:4 describes God’s mercy as being greater than what?
questions.correctAnswer: Above the heavens
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:4 says, 'For thy mercy is great above the heavens: and thy truth reacheth unto the clouds.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 108:5 ask God to be exalted above?
options: The heavens and all the earth
All the kings of the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens and all the earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:5 states, 'Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth;'

questions.question: In Psalms 108:6, what is requested to save the beloved?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy right hand
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:6 says, 'save with thy right hand, and answer me.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:7, what will the psalmist divide and mete out?
options: Shechem and the valley of Succoth
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem and the valley of Succoth
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:7 states, 'I will divide Shechem, and mete out the valley of Succoth.'

questions.question: Which tribes or regions are mentioned as belonging to God in Psalms 108:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, Judah
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:8 states, 'Gilead is mine; Manasseh is mine; Ephraim also is the strength of mine head; Judah is my lawgiver;'

questions.question: Psalms 108:9 uses a metaphor about Moab, what is Moab described as?
questions.correctAnswer: My washpot
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:9 says, 'Moab is my washpot;'

questions.question: Who does the psalmist ask to bring him into the strong city in Psalms 108:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will bring me
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:10 asks, 'Who will bring me into the strong city? who will lead me into Edom?'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 108:11 questions if God will go forth with the hosts after having cast them off.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:11 says, 'Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off? and wilt not thou, O God, go forth with our hosts?'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 108:12, help from man is sufficient in times of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:12 says, 'Give us help from trouble: for vain is the help of man.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 108:13 states that through God we shall do valiantly and tread down enemies.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:13 states, 'Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies.'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 108:5: 'Be thou exalted, O God, above the ______: and thy glory above all the earth;'
questions.correctAnswer: heavens
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:5 reads, 'Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth;'

questions.question: Complete the verse from Psalms 108:3: 'I will praise thee, O LORD, among the ______: and I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.'
questions.correctAnswer: people
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:3 says, 'I will praise thee, O LORD, among the people: and I will sing praises unto thee among the nations.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 108 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 108 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 108, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult times?
options: Through God we shall do valiantly and He will tread down our enemies
Rely on human strength and plans to overcome trouble
Ignore prayer and depend solely on your own wisdom
Seek revenge on those who cause your trouble
questions.correctAnswer: Through God we shall do valiantly and He will tread down our enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:13 teaches that through God we can act valiantly, and He helps us overcome adversaries. This encourages faith and reliance on God's strength rather than human resources (Psalms 108:12, Psalms 108:6).

questions.question: How does Psalms 108:1-3 encourage personal devotion and worship in Christian life?
options: Fix your heart on God and sing praises early with your whole being
Wait until others start worship before you join
Keep your worship private and silent
Focus only on your own glory, not God’s
questions.correctAnswer: Fix your heart on God and sing praises early with your whole being
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares his heart is fixed on God and commits to singing praises even with his glory (Psalms 108:1-3). This models wholehearted, disciplined worship and devotion.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:4-5, what practical lesson about God’s nature and our attitude toward Him can be drawn for Christian living?
options: Recognize God’s great mercy and truth and exalt Him above all
Ignore God’s mercy and focus on earthly success
Trust only in what you see and understand
Be humble but not praise God publicly
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize God’s great mercy and truth and exalt Him above all
questions.explanation: The psalmist acknowledges God’s mercy above the heavens and truth reaching to the clouds, calling believers to exalt God above all earth (Psalms 108:4-5). This teaches humility and gratitude.

questions.question: A believer struggling with discouragement asks how to find hope. What does Psalms 108:6-7 teach about God’s deliverance and assurance?
options: God delivers His beloved by His right hand and His holy word brings joy
Hope depends on luck and human effort alone
God does not respond to requests for help
questions.correctAnswer: God delivers His beloved by His right hand and His holy word brings joy
questions.explanation: Verse 6 calls on God to save His beloved by His right hand, and verse 7 expresses joy in God’s holy promise. This encourages believers to trust God’s power and faithfulness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 108:8-9 illustrate God’s sovereignty and what practical attitude should a Christian have about God’s rule over all things?
options: God claims all regions and triumphs over enemies, so trust His sovereign power
God only cares for some people and not others
Humans must fight all battles alone
God’s rule is limited and uncertain
questions.correctAnswer: God claims all regions and triumphs over enemies, so trust His sovereign power
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 depict God’s dominion over territories and enemies, reminding believers to submit to His supreme authority and find confidence in His control.

questions.question: What practical lesson about prayer and dependence on God is taught in Psalms 108:10-11?
options: Ask God to lead and not abandon His people, acknowledging our need for His presence
Rely on human leaders without seeking God’s guidance
Ignore God’s help and depend on self only
Stop praying if God delays answers
questions.correctAnswer: Ask God to lead and not abandon His people, acknowledging our need for His presence
questions.explanation: The psalmist questions who will lead him into battle and pleads with God not to cast off His people, highlighting the importance of seeking God’s guidance and presence (Psalms 108:10-11).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by problems and asks if human help is sufficient. What does Psalms 108:12 say about relying on human help versus God’s help?
options: Help from man is vain; true help comes from God
Human help is always enough in every situation
Ignore God and trust only in friends
Avoid asking for help from anyone
questions.correctAnswer: Help from man is vain; true help comes from God
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that help from man is vain, emphasizing that God’s help is the only truly effective aid in times of trouble.

questions.question: How does Psalms 108:1-3 teach us about the discipline of early morning devotion and worship?
options: Awake early to praise God with musical instruments and sing praises
Delay worship until the evening only
Worship only when feeling inspired, no set time needed
Ignore regular worship and focus on work
questions.correctAnswer: Awake early to praise God with musical instruments and sing praises
questions.explanation: Verse 2 commands the psaltery and harp to awake early, and the psalmist commits to early praise, illustrating the discipline of morning worship.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 108:13, our victory over enemies depends solely on our own valor and strength.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:13 states that it is through God that we do valiantly and tread down enemies, not by our own strength alone.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 108:5 encourages believers to exalt God’s glory above all the earth.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 5 calls for God to be exalted above the heavens and His glory above all the earth, encouraging believers to honor God supremely.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:7-9, the psalmist mentions several regions and nations. What does this teach about God’s role in our work and conflicts?
options: God claims authority over territories and enables victory, so trust Him in your struggles
God is uninvolved in our conflicts and we must handle them alone
Focus only on personal gain not God’s kingdom
Avoid any involvement in challenges or battles
questions.correctAnswer: God claims authority over territories and enables victory, so trust Him in your struggles
questions.explanation: The psalmist declares God’s ownership and power over regions, signifying that God is sovereign in our conflicts and work, encouraging trust in His guidance and victory.

questions.question: How does Psalms 108:3 encourage believers in evangelism and sharing the Gospel?
options: Praise God among the peoples and sing praises among the nations
Keep faith private and avoid sharing with others
Only share the Gospel with close friends
Focus on worldly achievements instead of God’s message
questions.correctAnswer: Praise God among the peoples and sing praises among the nations
questions.explanation: Verse 3 encourages praising God publicly among all peoples and nations, which reflects a heart for evangelism and being a witness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Psalms 108:9, 'Moab is my _______; over Edom will I cast out my shoe; over Philistia will I triumph.'
questions.correctAnswer: washpot
questions.explanation: Verse 9 uses 'washpot' to symbolize submission or subjugation, showing God’s triumph over enemies.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:6, what should believers pray for regarding God’s beloved?
options: That they may be delivered and saved by God’s right hand
That they rely solely on their own strength
That they face punishment without mercy
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be delivered and saved by God’s right hand
questions.explanation: Verse 6 expresses a plea for deliverance and salvation by God’s powerful right hand, teaching believers to pray for God’s protection over His people.

questions.question: How does Psalms 108:11-12 teach about humility and recognizing our limitations?
options: Acknowledge that without God’s help, human efforts are in vain
Trust only in human armies and strategies
Boast in personal achievement without God
Ignore the need for God in difficult times
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledge that without God’s help, human efforts are in vain
questions.explanation: Verses 11-12 highlight God’s necessity for success and that human help alone is worthless, encouraging humility and dependence on God.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 108 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 108.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:1, what does David declare about his heart in relation to God?
questions.correctAnswer: My heart is fixed
questions.explanation: David states in Psalms 108:1, 'O God, my heart is fixed; I will sing and give praise,' indicating his unwavering commitment to praise God.

questions.question: What musical instruments does David call to awaken in Psalms 108:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Psaltery and harp
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:2 reads, 'Awake, psaltery and harp,' calling these stringed instruments to accompany his early morning praise.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:3, among whom will David sing praises to the LORD?
options: Among the people and the nations
Among the priests and the elders
Among the angels and heavenly hosts
questions.correctAnswer: Among the people and the nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:3 states, 'I will praise thee, O LORD, among the people: and I will sing praises unto thee among the nations,' indicating a universal scope of praise.

questions.question: What two divine attributes does David exalt in Psalms 108:4?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and truth
questions.explanation: In Psalms 108:4, David praises God's 'mercy' as great above the heavens and His 'truth' as reaching unto the clouds, highlighting divine steadfastness.

questions.question: Psalms 108:5 calls for God to be exalted above what?
options: Above the heavens and all the earth
Above the temple and the sanctuary
questions.correctAnswer: Above the heavens and all the earth
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth,' emphasizing God's supreme sovereignty.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:6, what does David ask God to do for His beloved?
options: Deliver them and save with His right hand
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver them and save with His right hand
questions.explanation: David prays in Psalms 108:6, 'That thy beloved may be delivered: save with thy right hand, and answer me,' seeking God's powerful intervention.

questions.question: Which places does David mention as possessions of God in Psalms 108:7-8?
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem, Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, Judah
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 8 list these lands as belonging to God or under His authority, highlighting Israel's tribal regions.

questions.question: What symbolic action does David mention regarding Edom in Psalms 108:9?
options: Casting out his shoe over Edom
questions.correctAnswer: Casting out his shoe over Edom
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:9 says, 'over Edom will I cast out my shoe,' a symbolic gesture of conquest and dominance in ancient Near Eastern culture.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:10, who does David ask to bring him into the strong city and lead him into Edom?
options: Who will bring me into the strong city?
questions.correctAnswer: Who will bring me into the strong city?
questions.explanation: David poses a rhetorical question in Psalms 108:10, seeking divine leadership into strongholds and enemy territory.

questions.question: True or False: In Psalms 108:11, David accuses God of completely forsaking them and asks if He will not go with their hosts.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse reads, 'Wilt not thou, O God, who hast cast us off? and wilt not thou, O God, go forth with our hosts?', expressing a plea amid perceived abandonment.

questions.question: What reason does David give in Psalms 108:12 for why help from man is insufficient?
options: Because the help of man is vain
questions.correctAnswer: Because the help of man is vain
questions.explanation: David acknowledges the futility of human help in Psalms 108:12, emphasizing reliance on divine aid.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:13, through whom shall we do valiantly and tread down our enemies?
questions.correctAnswer: Through God
questions.explanation: David declares in Psalms 108:13, 'Through God we shall do valiantly: for he it is that shall tread down our enemies,' attributing victory to divine power.

questions.question: The phrase 'I will divide Shechem, and mete out the valley of Succoth' in Psalms 108:7 likely refers to what type of action?
questions.correctAnswer: A military or territorial division
questions.explanation: The action suggests allotting or conquering land, fitting the context of David's rejoicing and God's promise of victory in verse 7.

questions.question: What literary device is prominent in Psalms 108:4 with the phrases 'thy mercy is great above the heavens' and 'thy truth reacheth unto the clouds'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The two lines mirror each other in structure and meaning, a hallmark of Hebrew poetic parallelism seen in verse 4.

questions.question: How does the mention of tribal lands like Manasseh, Ephraim, and Judah in Psalms 108:8 reflect the historical context of ancient Israel?
options: It underscores the unity and territorial claims of Israel's tribes under God
It denotes the division and conflict among tribes
It refers to foreign nations allied with Israel
It symbolizes spiritual regions rather than physical lands
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores the unity and territorial claims of Israel's tribes under God
questions.explanation: Verse 8 lists these tribes as God's possession, reflecting the historical tribal organization and divine sovereignty over Israel.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 108 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 108 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:1, what is the condition of David's heart as he begins his song?
options: Fixed and ready to sing and praise
questions.correctAnswer: Fixed and ready to sing and praise
questions.explanation: Psalms 108:1 states, 'O God, my heart is fixed; I will sing and give praise, even with my glory.' This reflects a heart steadfastly committed to worship. Similar steadfastness is seen in Psalm 57:7, Psalm 112:7, Philippians 4:7, and James 5:8.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:4, what two divine attributes are described as reaching beyond the heavens and clouds?
questions.correctAnswer: Mercy and truth
questions.explanation: Verse 4 highlights God's 'mercy is great above the heavens' and 'thy truth reacheth unto the clouds,' emphasizing His infinite compassion and faithfulness. This aligns with Exodus 34:6, Psalm 36:5, Lamentations 3:22, and John 1:14.

questions.question: Psalms 108:5 calls for God to be exalted above what?
options: The heavens and all the earth
questions.correctAnswer: The heavens and all the earth
questions.explanation: Verse 5 says, 'Be thou exalted, O God, above the heavens: and thy glory above all the earth,' affirming God's supreme sovereignty. This is consistent with Isaiah 6:1, Psalm 113:4, Revelation 4:11, and Colossians 1:16.

questions.question: What request does David make in Psalms 108:6 regarding God’s beloved?
options: That they may be delivered by God's right hand
That they be given wealth and power
That they be hidden from their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: That they may be delivered by God's right hand
questions.explanation: David asks for deliverance for God's beloved through His powerful right hand, underscoring divine rescue (Psalms 108:6). Similar themes appear in Exodus 15:6, Psalm 20:6, Isaiah 41:10, and Romans 8:31.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:7, what geographical locations does David mention to demonstrate God’s promise and his rejoicing?
options: Shechem and the valley of Succoth
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem and the valley of Succoth
questions.explanation: David states he will divide Shechem and mete out the valley of Succoth, indicating God’s sovereign promise over the land (Psalms 108:7). This is echoed in Joshua 24:32, Judges 1:34, Genesis 33:18, and Hebrews 11:9.

questions.question: According to Psalms 108:8, which tribes or regions are declared as belonging to God?
questions.correctAnswer: Gilead, Manasseh, Ephraim, and Judah
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states these regions as God's possession, highlighting His covenantal relationship and authority (Psalms 108:8). Similar affirmations are found in Deuteronomy 33:17, Joshua 17:14, Judges 5:14, and Romans 11:26.

questions.question: What symbolic act does God declare over Edom in Psalms 108:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Casting out His shoe
questions.explanation: David proclaims, 'over Edom will I cast out my shoe,' symbolizing dominion and conquest (Psalms 108:9). This act is reflected in Ruth 4:7, Joshua 5:15, Psalm 60:8, and Romans 11:11.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:10, David asks who will lead him into two specific places. What are they?
questions.correctAnswer: The strong city and Edom
questions.explanation: David questions who will bring him into the strong city and lead him into Edom, expressing dependency on divine guidance (Psalms 108:10). This theme aligns with Psalm 27:3, Isaiah 37:33, Jeremiah 6:1, and Hebrews 13:5.

questions.question: What is David's plea in Psalms 108:11 regarding God's presence with the hosts?
options: That God would go forth with the hosts and not cast them off
That the hosts be given strength and victory without God
That God remain silent and watch over the battle
That God punish the hosts for their sins
questions.correctAnswer: That God would go forth with the hosts and not cast them off
questions.explanation: David appeals for God's presence with the army, highlighting the necessity of divine accompaniment for success (Psalms 108:11). This is consistent with Exodus 33:14, Psalm 44:3, Joshua 1:9, and 2 Chronicles 20:15.

questions.question: Psalms 108:12 contrasts the help of man with what kind of help?
options: Help from God, which is effective
Help from angels, which is uncertain
Help from friends, which is reliable
Help from leaders, which is sufficient
questions.correctAnswer: Help from God, which is effective
questions.explanation: David declares human help as vain and asks for God's help in trouble, emphasizing God's sufficiency (Psalms 108:12). This is parallel to Psalm 20:7, Isaiah 31:1, Jeremiah 17:5, and John 15:5.

questions.question: What confidence does David express in Psalms 108:13 regarding God’s role in battle?
options: That through God they shall do valiantly and tread down enemies
That their own strength will secure victory
That alliances with other nations will win the fight
That peace will come without conflict
questions.correctAnswer: That through God they shall do valiantly and tread down enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 13 declares victory through God’s power, affirming God's role as the divine warrior (Psalms 108:13). Corresponding passages include Exodus 15:3, Psalm 18:39, Isaiah 42:13, and Romans 8:37.

questions.question: What instruments does David call to awake in Psalms 108:2 as part of his praise?
questions.correctAnswer: Psaltery and harp
questions.explanation: David calls psaltery and harp to awake early for praise, signifying the use of musical worship (Psalms 108:2). Similar calls are found in Psalm 33:2, 1 Chronicles 15:16, Psalm 150:3, and Ephesians 5:19.

questions.question: In Psalms 108:3, David commits to praising God among which groups?
options: Among the people and the nations
Among the elders and the young
questions.correctAnswer: Among the people and the nations
questions.explanation: David declares praise to God among both people and nations, reflecting the universal scope of worship (Psalms 108:3). This is supported by Psalm 67:3, Isaiah 12:4, Revelation 7:9, and Matthew 28:19.

questions.question: Psalms 108:9 mentions Moab as what symbolic object, indicating subjugation?
questions.correctAnswer: A washpot
questions.explanation: Moab is called a 'washpot,' a lowly object, symbolizing subjugation (Psalms 108:9). This metaphor of dominion appears in Judges 3:31, 2 Samuel 8:2, Isaiah 14:2, and Romans 15:12.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of David's declaration in Psalms 108:7 where God 'hath spoken in his holiness'?
options: God’s holy word is decisive and brings rejoicing and victory
God’s speech is silent but powerful
God’s holiness is distant and unapproachable
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holy word is decisive and brings rejoicing and victory
questions.explanation: David rejoices because God's holy word is authoritative, resulting in triumph (Psalms 108:7). Similar affirmations are found in Isaiah 55:11, Psalm 119:140, John 17:17, and Hebrews 4:12.
